body:
>P.S. Thanks a lot for the hard work on this great package!

You're welcome, much appreciated! ðŸ˜„ 

>I'd be happy to help with a PR.

@aiwalter, can you have a look at this, since it concerns your components?
I thought we already had sth like this?

Hm, this is similar to #1486 - maybe we should think about reworking the `get_fitted_params` interface so it always returns sth (e.g., the most likely thing users may look for)?

FYI @asksteph

In the case of linear models, in addition to the coefficients, getting the corresponding feature names would be really helpful. Sklearn has feature_names_in_ as an attribute in versions >= 1.0, but are those sklearn versions incompatible with sktime right now?

What you're proposing, @fkiraly, may be one step more advanced than my proposal. If I understand well, you would like the get_fitted_params interface to return a predefined subset of information from the fitted Estimator that the end user likely wants to obtain. E.g. the .coef_ of an ARIMA model.

I meant to propose to make the full fitted Estimator accessible, without the need to define per Estimator which information should be returned. Then, the end user can decide for him/herself what information to obtain, using attributes and methods of the fitted Estimator. (e.g. using model.coeff_ or model.summary())

As you mention in #1486, the coefficients of a reduced regressor can be obtained by forecaster.estimator_.coef_ or forecaster.estimators_[0].coef_ 

This is no longer the case when using a Transformedtargetforecaster

Just found out there is already a solution to my problem! The fitted model is stored in `steps_`, while I was looking for it in `steps` or `named_steps`. This gives the desired result:
```
best_forecaster= grid.best_forecaster_.steps_[1][1]
best_forecaster.summary()
```

rename.from: [ENH] Accessing fitted BaseForecaster after fitting a TransformedTargetForecaster or ForecastingGridSearchCV

body:
Ok, so you have a workaround for this, @boukepostma - should have mentioned that you can just dig into the estimator and get it out - that always works if you know what the attribute is called.

But, this is also a case where `get_fitted_params` would be useful, so changing the title to that.

There is perhaps also a documentation issue here, @aiwalter?

issue.title: [ENH] get_fitted_params umbrella issue

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Collecting some issues related to implementing meaningful `get_fitted_params` methods.

General framework:

- [x] nested interface like `get_params` #971

Individual estimators:

- [x] (Auto)ARIMA #962

For composite forecasters:

- [x] tuning forecasters #1496 
- [x] reduction forecasters #1486 
- [ ] forecasting pipelines #1468 

FYI @boukepostma, @asksteph, @aiwalter 

Sounds like an interesting project?

body:
Update: the `get_fitted_params` interface has been reworked, now there is a separation into `get_fitted_params` (boilerplate) and `_get_fitted_params`.

The correct locus for implementing this functionality would now be in `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` rather than in the specific pipeline class.

rename.to: [ENH] Implement `get_fitted_params` for pipelines and heterogeneous ensembles

issue.title: [ENH] `get_fitted_params` for pipelines and other heterogenous meta-estimators

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds full functionality for `get_fitted_params` of pipelines (incl forecasting pipelines) and other heterogenous meta-estimators. Fixes https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1468

`get_fitted_params` would already work previously, but not crawl the estimators in the "fitted steps" for fitted parameters.

This is now added, by adding a `_steps_fitted_attr` to configure in the `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator`, which is then used to retrieve the fitted parameters. In effect, this PR adds more keys and values that are retrieved to the return of `get_fitted_params`, from crawling the fitted steps.

Further updates the `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` with a relaxed interface assumption: the `_steps_attr` now only needs to be an iterable of tuples of which the 0-th element is the name, 1-st element is an estimator. This covers, for instance, the `ColumnEnsembleForecaster` and the `ColumnEnsembleClassifier` natively, for both `get_params` (existing feature) and the new `get_fitted_params` functionality.

FYI @RNKuhns as this concerns an `skbase` object, would be keen to hear your opinion.
